support.p: Five plates. Each 9 inches wide and 1.9 inches high. They are held together by a ring (0.3 inches in thickness) passing through a hole (0.5 inches in diameter). The joint of the ring is soldered to an elliptical seal which bears the figure of an animal facing proper right and a legend.

history.provenance: Penukoṇḍa, in the West Godavari District, Andhra Pradesh. Sent to the Government Epigraphist by Mr. R. V. Krishna Rao of Rajahmundry.

div.p: This edition is based on Sircar 1963–1964.

div.ab:
siddhaṃ | vijaya-jayapurā bhagavan-nārāyaṇa-caraṇāravinda
rajovaguṇḍita-śirassa vāsa-satāyukassa mahāraja-sirī-

hatthivammassa vayaṇeṇa kānīrāhāre appaṇo
dhammāyu-bala-vivaddhaṇatthaṃ svarnnayanārtthañca

amha-punn-appāyana-nimitte mulukuli-muduḍa-ppamu
hāho gāmo bhāṇitavvo | etaṃ gaāmaṃ nānā-gotra-caraṇa-

kalyāṇa-dakṣiṇa-nimitte saṃpa | taṃ devatatthattheṇa
savva-bādha-parīhārehi pariharadha | ā-chanda-tārakaṃ

bhuñjantu | dabe savaccharerā jeṭṭha-māsa-kālaṭṭhamiyaya
sa-muhāṇattī bhadrapada-nakṣatre saṃpadattaṃ || bahubhirvvasu
dhā dattā bahubhiścānupālitā |

yasya yasya yadā bhūmis tasya tasya tadā phalam ||
saṣḍiṣṭi-varṣa-sahasrāṇi svaggirgge modati bhūmidaḥ | apaharttā cānumantā ca
tāvan narakam ṛcchati || amāttya-jayasvāmīminā |

div.p: Let there be success! From the victorious Jayapura, the villagers of Mulukuli in the Kānīra district, headed by (their) mutuḍa, should be addressed in the (following) words of the illustrious Mahārāja Hastivarman who is one hundred years old and whose head is covered with the pollens of the lotus that is the feet of Lord Nārāyaṇa:

“For the increase of our virtue, longevity and strength and for our passage to heaven, (and also) for our attainment of religious merit,—this village is granted by us as the dakṣiṇa of the first kalyāṇa (ceremony), to the sixty Brāhmaṇas (i.e. the priests who performed the ceremony) who belong to various gotras and caraṇas; who are engaged in penance, recitation of sacred texts, offering of oblations to gods, observance of vows and religious austerities; who are experts in the veda, vedāṅga, tradition (itihāsa), purāṇa, medical science (nīroga), metrical science (chandovicita) and the exposition of texts (pravacana); and who are (also) engaged in the six duties (of the Brāhmaṇas, such as) study, teaching, offering sacrifices, conducting sacrifices, charity, and receipt of gifts. Exempt the said (village), for the god’s (i.e., Nārāyaṇa’s) sake, with all exemptions from obstacles. Let (the donees) enjoy (it) as long as the moon and stars endure. (It) is given by the orders from our own mouth on the dark eighth (i.e., the eighth of the dark fortnight) of the month of Jyeṣṭha when the nakṣatra is Bhādrapada and the (regnal) years are (to be counted as) two.”
(Two of the usual imprecatory and benedictory stanzas.)
